children.subject: how is math110 vs 16b in terms of workload/difficulty?

16b has way more workload: long prob set, long lab, two discussion each week. But the midterm is pretty straight forward. Also this semester 16b pay back 90% your lost points for homework so it's a little bit less stressful.

110 only has 5-6 questions for homework each week, and the GSI only pick 2 to grade. But they really emphasis on rigorously proving things from axioms, and the concepts of 110 are really abstract. The exam of 110 is also proof-based, could be pretty hard if you don't clearly understand each concept.

Also, different professors have completely different grading/teaching style for math110. This semester prof. Holtz is teaching it.

I'm currently taking 16B and 110 this semester; I'll share my two cents.

I spend 15-20 hours/week on 110 (this includes lectures, reading the textbook, and working on homework). I came into 110 with a relatively weak linear algebra background having barely scraped by 16A. Although weekly homework sets are only 5-6 questions, they are hard for the average student coming from 16A/54. Prof. Holtz's exams are also hard (~45% mean). With Prof. Holtz, Math 110 is much more difficult than 16B.

With that said, if you are serious about understanding linear algebra deeply, I strongly encourage taking Math 110. 110 has complemented the linear algebra in 16B pretty well this semester and as a result, some 16B problem sets take me just a couple hours. 

Overall, I would say that the classes are similar in workload, and although 110 is more difficult, a good understanding of 110 helps significantly in understanding linear algebra concepts in 16B.
I'm in both right now and they are teaching lin alg through different angle. Definitely worth taking if you want a really deep understanding of lin alg.

history.content: I think it depends how comfortable you are with 16B, and who's teaching 110. I took 110 after 16AB + 54 with Frenkel (Spring 2018), he mostly repeated things I had seen before, but I didn't have a good grasp and it greatly helped me solidify my linear algebra fundamentals. Had I better internalized 16AB when I took them, I don't think it would have been as useful. If your foundations are weak, I'd recommend Frenkel's offering. I'm not sure what it's like with other professors.
Is it worth taking math 110 if I’ve already taken 16B? I’ve heard there’s a substantial amount of overlapping content
